mcqs.q: What is the primary purpose of a randomized controlled test (RCT)?
options: To collect qualitative data from participants
To observe trends in historical data
To determine causal relationships by comparing treatment and control groups
To generate public opinion surveys

mcqs.q: What are confounders in the context of causal inference?
options: Variables that can have an effect on the outcome but are not accounted for
Data points that are consistently accurate
Participants who refuse to follow the treatment protocol
External factors affecting the test environment

mcqs.q: What challenge arises when the treatment group does not represent the overall population?
options: Confounding variable
Selection bias
Counterfactuals
Statistical insignificance

mcqs.q: In causal inference, why are counterfactuals important?
options: They provide a way to eliminate bias
They help to measure how different factors interact
They allow for an apples-to-apples comparison of outcomes
They simplify the data collection process

mcqs.q: What does the Stable Unit Treatment Value Assumption (SUTVA) assert?
options: The treatment has no effect on individuals receiving a placebo
Sample units do not influence each otherâ€™s treatment outcomes
The control group should have more variability than the treatment group
All treatments must be applied at the same time

mcqs.q: Which technique can be used to calculate counterfactual outcomes in observational data?
options: Descriptive statistics
Machine learning
Subjective analysis
Meta-analysis

mcqs.q: What did the example in the transcript demonstrate about the average treatment effect (ATE) of the elixir?
options: It is constant across all age groups
It can be overestimated if confounders are not controlled for
It can only be measured through randomized controlled tests
It shows that younger people benefit more from the treatment

mcqs.q: How does the conditional average treatment effect (CATE) differ from the overall average treatment effect (ATE)?
options: CATE looks only at the overall population, while ATE focuses on individuals
CATE analyzes the effect of treatments on specific subgroups, while ATE does not
ATE considers the prior data, while CATE is found through experiments
CATE accounts for external variables, while ATE does not

mcqs.q: What assumption suggests that there are no unmeasured confounders that affect both treatment and outcome?
options: Causal Markov condition
SUTVA
Ignorability
Assumption of randomization

mcqs.q: What is treatment heterogeneity as discussed in the transcript?
options: The variation in treatment effectiveness across different groups
An equal treatment effect across all participants
The failure of the treatment to impact any group
The ability to measure treatment effects through qualitative data
